entry.title: Added Umami!
entry.summary:
After what seems like forever, I finally decided to post something for the first time on my blogpost.

Before we get into this post, I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux I am not affiliated by Umami in any way shape or form, I just find them neat.
entry.content:
After what seems like forever, I finally decided to post something for the first time on my blogpost.

Before we get into this post, I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux I am not affiliated by Umami in any way shape or form, I just find them neat.

Table of Contents

  • What is Umami?
  • Why Umami?
  • Conclusion
  • Links and References

What is Umami?

So, what is this Umami thing anyways? Umami is a FOSS (Free and Open-Source) and privacy-focused web analytics uhh.. thing. It helps web admins view visitor data and whatnot for their websites.

If you'd like to learn more (and get a better explanation), you can check out their website here.

Why Umami?

Why not just use Google Analytics or CloudFlare like any other sane person?

Some of you may wonder why I chose this over any other analytics solution like Google Analytics. It's because I care about my privacy and the privacy of visitors like you guys and gals who visit this website, plus, I'm not a big fan of Google anyways.

Another reason is that I can self-host Umami on my home server. I'll probably show my server some other time, but being able to self-host means that I control the data instead of some big corp. If you're curious, you can check out the analytics data over here.

Conclusion

So in short, Umami is an analytics platform that's free and respects users' privacy. I chose it because I don't want to use Google and because I can host Umami myself on my own server.

Do you guys think Umami is good? Or are there any better alternatives? Let me know, wait, you can't lol. I haven't added a comments system for this blog yet. But I'll probably add it eventuallyâ„¢. For now, there's not much to see here. Currently I don't have any other posts that I can promote but if you liked reading this then feel free to share this blog, I'd appreciate it.

Links and References

Here are all the important links in this page:

  • Umami - https://umami.is/
  • My analytics - https://stats.jeffersontan.xyz/share/Dq1Qz7b4KYzxvSAb/jeffersontan.xyz

entry.title: About Me
entry.summary: Tech Since I was very young, I like to tinker with tech, and I'm eager to learn about how things work If I want something to work the way I want it to, I will try to find a way to make it work. Usually…
entry.content:
Contents

  • Tech
    • Projects
      • Mechanic's Guide (2019)
      • GPU Detector Script (2024)
      • FFmpeg Accel Script (2024)
  • Games

Tech

Since I was very young, I like to tinker with tech, and I'm eager to learn about how things work

If I want something to work the way I want it to, I will try to find a way to make it work. Usually I would hunt forum posts or videos online for guides to do things, try it out, and see if things work. But sometimes... that can produce unintended results.

I've probably broken stuff in countless ways by now, some examples are: Bricking a phone, accidentally wiping a drive, and so on, but that's all part of the learning process. If I didn't fail, I wouldn't have the knowledge and experience that I have today.

Projects

Below are a few projects that I have done in the past

Mechanic's Guide (2019)

This is a website that I made for a high school project many years ago. It's coded using both HTML and CSS by hand, and since I used GitHub pages to host it, I learned a bit about code versioning.

GPU Detector Script (2024)

This was a small project I've made using Bash to learn more about Bash scripting and as a companion script for my other Bash project

FFmpeg Accel Script (2024)

This is mainly a script that I wrote to help myself convert videos faster and with less effort, but anyone else are free to use it. Uses some code from my GPU detection script. It is currently a work in progress but the basics are there.

Games

If I'm not tinkering with computers (either software or hardware), I usually play games on my computer. What kind of games you may ask? Mostly racing games as I really like cars, but I do play other genres occasionally.

If you're interested, you can check out my (mostly dead) YouTube channel where I post game-related stuff.

https://www.youtube.com/@jefferson-tan
